_prev_prog_3.Description: Castle Rock Vineyards has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is incompliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

?    California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

?    Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

?    California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

?    Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Castle Rock Vineyards has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1    CASTLE ROCK VINEYARDS, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Castle Rock Vineyards has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name     Process Chemical    Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia            Ammonia                   60,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Castle Rock Vineyards has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 



1.    Prepare

d a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2.    Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Castle Rock Vineyards business practices

3.    Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Castle Rock Vineyards employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.



1.2    PROCESS DESCRIPTION



The Castle Rock Vineyards facility is a commercial cold storage facility for table grapes. The facility has an ammonia system that provides refrigeration capacity to multiple cold rooms equipped with forced air tunnels for cooling fruit. Some rooms are designated as "precooling" rooms, while others are for cold storage. The rooms are equipped with "bunker style" and ceiling suspended evaporator coils that contain chilled liquid ammonia. There is a cooled loading dock area as well. A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability.



High pressure liquid from a high pressure receivers is piped to a main king valve. From there, high pressure liquid is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into a low pressure accumulator vessel. Low temperature liquid circulates by thermal convection through the evaporator coils located behind bunker walls in the cold rooms. Low pressure and temperature gas collects in the accumulator vessel, and passes through a pressure regulator into a suction line. The suction line returns the vapor to the main suction accumulator vessel, which separates any residual liquid from the gas. The gas is piped to compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to the high pressure receivers. Liquid separated from the suction return

gas in the main suction accumulator drains into liquid transfer vessels. Operation of a float switch activated solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessel to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receivers.



The facility was built by professional refrigeration engineers in accordance with industry standards at the time. It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. Recently the following major system modifications have occurred:

?    2006 - California Controlled Atmosphere installed the a new control system for the refrigeration system

?    2008 - California Controlled Atmosphere supplied and installed the refrigeration equipment for Rooms 15-18

?    2009 - California Controlled Atmosphere replaced the coils in Room 9

?    2010 - California Controlled Atmosphere moved a screw compressor from Plant 2 to Plant 1



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere or a water diffusion tank (Rooms 15-18) if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. In addition, ammonia detectors are located throughout the facility, and will shut down equipment if ammonia is detected. Lastly, an emergency "dump box" contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.



The ammonia system at this facility consists of equipment and vessels which are interconnected by piping. Therefore, the system is treated as a single process.



1.3    GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



1.3.1    GENERAL 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared

for a release.

Castle Rock Vineyards has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 



1.3.2    ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Castle Rock Vineyards facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Castle Rock Vineyards has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5    EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN



Castle Rock Vineyards' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

?    California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

?    Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 

?    California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

?    Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Ever

y year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Castle Rock Vineyards has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Castle Rock Vineyards continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Castle Rock Vineyards' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Castle Rock Vineyards' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Castle Rock Vineyards has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Castle Rock Vineyards has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.



For the future, Castle Rock Vineyards now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Castle Rock Vineyards employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Castle Rock Vineyards will continue to maintain overall plant worker and
